entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French enformer, from Latin informare, from in- + forma form

def.dt: :to give character or essence to the principles which inform modern teaching
:to be the characteristic quality of :animate the compassion that informs her work
:to communicate knowledge to inform a prisoner of his rights
:to give information (as of another's wrongdoing) to an authority informed on a member of his own gang

entry.pt: inform acquaint apprise notify mean to make one aware of something. inform implies the imparting of knowledge especially of facts or occurrences informed us of the crisis. acquaint lays stress on introducing to or familiarizing with acquaint yourself with the keyboard. apprise implies communicating something of special interest or importance keep us apprised of the situation. notify implies sending notice of something requiring attention or demanding action notified the witness when to appear.
